channel.title: Wellington City Council - News
channel.description: The latest news from Wellington City Council.

item.title: Traffic signals to be installed at Seatoun Tunnel
item.description: Work starts this Monday 6 May to install traffic signals outside both entrances to the Seatoun Tunnel in preparation for the upcoming earthquake strengthening.

item.title: Trans-Tasman artist exchange builds capital bond
item.description: The inaugural Canberra Wellington Indigenous Artist Exchange programme starts this month, with Canberra’s Dean Cross arriving in Wellington, and local artist Ana Iti going to Canberra on 28 May.

item.title: Wellington Mayor calls for insurance forum
item.description: Wellington Mayor Justin Lester is calling for a forum with the Government’s Earthquake Commission Minister, insurance companies, and affected stakeholders to discuss rising insurance premiums.

item.title: Council to consider panel’s recommendations on District Plan Change to extend Kiwi Point Quarry
item.description: An independent hearing panel has made recommendations on a decision on District Plan Change 83 for Kiwi Point Quarry, following public hearings in December 2018 – Wellington City Councillors will consider these recommendations on Wednesday 1 May 2019.

item.title: Beauty industry health issues - tell us your thoughts
item.description: Wellington City Council is reviewing its Public Health Bylaw and is seeking feedback from the industry and the public on any issues people experience with the health and beauty industry and whether they should be regulated.

item.title: Working together for te reo Māori in the capital
item.description: Wellington City Council and Te Taura Whiri i te Reo Māori have signed a mahi tahi agreement with the goal to work together on revitalising te reo Māori in the capital city.

item.title: On-going future-proofing of Ngaio Gorge starts this month
item.description: A permanent solution to stabilise the Ngaio Gorge, and make this key transport route stronger and more resilient, moves a step closer this month with the start of geotechnical investigations.

item.title: Easter and Anzac Day services and facilities information
item.description: With Easter and Anzac Day coming up, there are a number of events happening, and some changes to our services and opening hours of our facilities.

item.title: Wellington in the race to reach zero carbon
item.description: Wellington City Council is seeking feedback on Te Atakura – First to Zero: its blueprint for a zero carbon capital city, which was released today.

item.title: Longer library hours to meet demand
item.description: Wellington Mayor Justin Lester today confirmed on-going additional opening hours and days for some branch libraries in response to the closure of the Central Library.

item.title: Council preserves heritage as history doesn’t repeat itself
item.description: What do an Edwardian home, a yacht club, two chapels, and a couple of old warehouses have in common? They’re all recipients of the latest round of the Wellington City Council’s Built Heritage Incentive Fund – contributing towards seismic strengthening work and conservation around the capital.

item.title: Blessing marks start of harbour-side cycleway
item.description: A blessing was held at Omaru-kai-kuru/Pt Jerningham this morning ahead of construction starting after Easter on the first part of the planned new two-way bike path around Evans Bay.

item.title: Expressions of Interest open for Waitohi café
item.description: Wellington City Council is inviting Expressions of Interest (EOI) for the café at Waitohi, Johnsonville’s new community hub.

item.title: Pre-1930s character homes survey wins award
item.description: Wellington City Council and consultants Boffa Miskell have won a major award for their joint work on a recently-released review of inner-city residential areas characterised by pre-1930s houses.

item.title: Annual Plan ready for community input
item.description: Wellingtonians will have a four-week window to share their thoughts on Wellington City Council’s spending priorities for the coming year.

item.title: State of the arts gets a boost in the capital
item.description: A low budget film making challenge, a Samoan arts workshop, a glow in the dark puppet show, and queer and trans drawing classes are just a sample of the diverse recipients of this year’s Creative Communities Scheme (CCS).

item.title: Significant increase in residents support for Predator Free Wellington
item.description: Wellington residents are right behind the Predator Free Wellington project, and more people are rolling up their sleeves to get involved.

item.title: Local street art promotes moped rider safety
item.description: Wellington City Council is using street art from around the CBD to help promote safe riding to people on mopeds (small scooters up to 50cc), and encourage them to be aware of their surroundings.

item.title: First pop-up library service for CBD in Manners St
item.description: Wellington Mayor, Justin Lester, today announced the return of library services to the CBD with a new pop-up space set to open in Manners Street.

item.title: Council to celebrate local accessibility champions
item.description: Wellington City Accessibility Award nominations open this week in conjunction with the Wellington Airport Regional Community Awards – recognising organisations for their invaluable contribution to the community.
